On the SchrÃ¶dinger-Born-Infeld system

Abstract.

In this paper we study a system which we propose as a model to describe the interaction between matter and electromagnetic field from a dualistic point of view. This system arises from a suitable coupling of the SchrÃ¶dinger and the Born-Infeld lagrangians, this latter replacing the role that, classically, is played by the Maxwell lagrangian.
We use a variational approach to find an electrostatic radial ground state solution by means of suitable estimates on the functional of the action.

Key words and phrases:
SchrÃ¶dinger-Born-Infeld equation, nonlinear electromagnetic theory
2010 Mathematics Subject Classification:
35J50, 35J93, 35Q60
A. Azzollini and A. Pomponio are partially supported by a grant of the group GNAMPA of INDAM. A. Pomponio is partially supported also by FRA2016 of Politecnico di Bari. G. Siciliano is supported by Capes, CNPq and Fapesp, Brazil.

1. Introduction

In the recent years, several models have been proposed to provide a mathematical description of the interaction between a charged particle and the electromagnetic field generated by itself. According to two different philosophycal concepts, the way to perform a mathematical formulation can follow two different and, in some way, antithetical approaches.

The theory developed by Born and Infeld (see [7] and [8]) introduced the idea that both the matter and the electromagnetic field were expression of a unique physical entity. According to this unitarian point of view, the system giving a complete description of the dynamics arose variationally starting from a nonlinear version of the Maxwell lagrangian. This unitarian approach was also taken up by Benci and Fortunato in [4] (see also [1] and [12]).
On the other hand there is the dualistic point of view, based on the idea that the dynamics can be described coupling equations related with particles and equations related with the electromagnetic field through a suitable combination of the lagrangians. Starting from the results obtained by Benci and Fortunato [2], the literature is rich of papers studying models based on this latter point of view.
In the past, the duality matter-electromagnetic field was usually carried out by means of either SchrÃ¶dinger or Klein-Gordon lagrangian to provide the mathematical description of the particle, and of the Maxwell lagrangian, or higher order approximations (in the sense of Taylor series) of the Born-Infeld lagrangian (see for example [13] and [9]) to represent the electromagnetic field.

Recently, Yu has proposed in [16] a dualistic model obtained coupling Klein-Gordon and Born-Infeld lagrangians and has studied the electrostatic case expressed by the following system

(ğ’¦â€‹ğ’¢â€‹â„¬â€‹â„ğ’¦ğ’¢â„¬â„\mathcal{KGBI}) {âˆ’Î”â€‹u+(m2âˆ’(Ï‰+Ï•)2)â€‹u=|u|pâˆ’1â€‹uÂ inÂ â€‹â„3,divâ¡(âˆ‡Ï•1âˆ’|âˆ‡Ï•|2)=u2â€‹(Ï‰+Ï•)Â inÂ â€‹â„3,uâ€‹(x)â†’0,Ï•â€‹(x)â†’0,Â asÂ â€‹xâ†’âˆ.casesÎ”ğ‘¢superscriptğ‘š2superscriptğœ”italic-Ï•2ğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢ğ‘1ğ‘¢Â inÂ superscriptâ„3divâˆ‡italic-Ï•1superscriptâˆ‡italic-Ï•2superscriptğ‘¢2ğœ”italic-Ï•Â inÂ superscriptâ„3formulae-sequenceâ†’ğ‘¢ğ‘¥0â†’italic-Ï•ğ‘¥0â†’Â asÂ ğ‘¥\begin{cases}-\Delta u+(m^{2}-(\omega+\phi)^{2})u=|u|^{p-1}u&\hbox{ in }{\mathbb{R}^{3}},\\[8.53581pt] \operatorname{div}\left(\dfrac{\nabla\phi}{\sqrt{1-|\nabla\phi|^{2}}}\right)=u^{2}(\omega+\phi)&\hbox{ in }{\mathbb{R}^{3}},\\ u(x)\to 0,\ \phi(x)\to 0,&\hbox{ as }x\to\infty.\end{cases}

As a consequence of the form of the differential operator in the second equation, a variational approach to the problem can not be performed in the usual functional spaces. In particular, the quantity 1/1âˆ’|âˆ‡Ï•â€‹(x)|211superscriptâˆ‡italic-Ï•ğ‘¥21/\sqrt{1-|\nabla\phi(x)|^{2}} makes sense when xâˆˆâ„3ğ‘¥superscriptâ„3x\in{\mathbb{R}^{3}} is such that |âˆ‡Ï•â€‹(x)|<1âˆ‡italic-Ï•ğ‘¥1|\nabla\phi(x)|<1, being this inequality a necessary constraint to be considered in the functional setting.

Inspired by [16], our aim is to propose and study a new model which represents a variant of the well-known SchrÃ¶dinger-Maxwell system as it was introduced in [10]. Indeed we replace the usual Maxwell lagrangian with the Born-Infeld one and we look for the electrostatic solutions. The system in this case becomes

(ğ’®â€‹â„¬â€‹â„ğ’®â„¬â„\mathcal{SBI}) {âˆ’Î”â€‹u+u+Ï•â€‹u=|u|pâˆ’1â€‹uÂ inÂ â€‹â„3,âˆ’divâ¡(âˆ‡Ï•1âˆ’|âˆ‡Ï•|2)=u2Â inÂ â€‹â„3,uâ€‹(x)â†’0,Ï•â€‹(x)â†’0,Â asÂ â€‹xâ†’âˆ,casesÎ”ğ‘¢ğ‘¢italic-Ï•ğ‘¢superscriptğ‘¢ğ‘1ğ‘¢Â inÂ superscriptâ„3divâˆ‡italic-Ï•1superscriptâˆ‡italic-Ï•2superscriptğ‘¢2Â inÂ superscriptâ„3formulae-sequenceâ†’ğ‘¢ğ‘¥0â†’italic-Ï•ğ‘¥0â†’Â asÂ ğ‘¥\begin{cases}-\Delta u+u+\phi u=|u|^{p-1}u&\hbox{ in }{\mathbb{R}^{3}},\\[8.53581pt] -\operatorname{div}\left(\dfrac{\nabla\phi}{\sqrt{1-|\nabla\phi|^{2}}}\right)=u^{2}&\hbox{ in }{\mathbb{R}^{3}},\\ u(x)\to 0,\ \phi(x)\to 0,&\hbox{ as }x\to\infty,\end{cases}

and we will refer to it as SchrÃ¶dinger-Born-Infeld system.

Our main results are the following

Theorem 1.2.

For any pâˆˆ(5/2,5)ğ‘525p\in(5/2,5), the problem (ğ’®â€‹â„¬â€‹â„ğ’®â„¬â„\mathcal{SBI}) possesses a radial ground state solution, namely a solution (u,Ï•)âˆˆHr1â€‹(â„3)Ã—ğ’³rğ‘¢italic-Ï•subscriptsuperscriptğ»1ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptâ„3subscriptğ’³ğ‘Ÿ(u,\phi)\in H^{1}_{r}({\mathbb{R}^{3}})\times\mathcal{X}_{r} minimizing the functional Fğ¹F among all the nontrivial radial solutions. Moreover both uğ‘¢u and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi are of class C2â€‹(â„3)superscriptğ¶2superscriptâ„3C^{2}({\mathbb{R}^{3}}).

What immediately stands out is the unusual range where pğ‘p varies. It follows from the fact that, in view of the application of the mountain pass theorem, we need to find a point with a sufficiently large norm where the functional is negative. In order to do this, usually one computes the reduced one-variable functional Iğ¼I on curves of the type

tâˆˆ(0,+âˆ)â†¦ut:=tÎ±u(tÎ²â‹…)âˆˆHr1(â„3),t\in(0,+\infty)\mapsto u_{t}:=t^{\alpha}u(t^{\beta}\cdot)\in H^{1}_{r}({\mathbb{R}^{3}}),

and look for suitable values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta for which Iâ€‹(ut)<0ğ¼subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¡0I(u_{t})<0 for large values of tğ‘¡t. However, in our case, because of the lack of homogeneity and since a precise expression of Ï•utsubscriptitalic-Ï•subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘¡\phi_{u_{t}} is not available, we need to proceed by means of estimates of Ï•usubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¢\phi_{u} which lead, as a consequence, to lose something in terms of powers pğ‘p.

Summing up, our aim in this paper is to propose the new model problem (ğ’®â€‹â„¬â€‹â„ğ’®â„¬â„\mathcal{SBI}) and give a positive answer concerning the existence of solutions, at least for pâˆˆ(5/2,5)ğ‘525p\in(5/2,5). We leave as an open problem the case of smaller pğ‘p and the existence of non-radial solutions.

The paper is organized as follows: in Section 2 we introduce the functional setting and present some preliminary results, while in Section 3 we prove Theorem 1.2.

We finish this section with some notations. 3. Proofs of the main results
